title: 2023 Polish parliamentary election
text:
Welcome to the 2023 Polish Election Dashboard
    This dashboard aggregates data from the Meta Ad Library to show how citizens are targeted during the 2023 Polish parliamentary election.
    If you want to know more about Who Targets Me and our work on ad transparency, visit us on whotargets.me!
  





2023 Polish parliamentary election
This section shows total and daily spending of political parties in the run-up to the 2023 Polish parliamentary election for the latest available data.


Topline Statistics

 Meta Google Combined



Sep 19th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 30 days)Oct 12th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 7 days)

title: ğŸ‡µğŸ‡± 2023 Polish Election Dashboard
text:
Methodology
In collaboration with Who Targets Me, we monitored 584 political advertisers in Poland during the 2023 Polish parliamentary election to better understand how campaigns use different targeting methods made available by Meta. To do this, we used data from the Meta Ad Library, using the new â€˜Audienceâ€™ data which gives some detail on how pages target their ads.
To better understand the election, we kept only advertisers who:

Advertised in the last 7 days (Oct 12th - Oct 18th 2023)
Advertised in the last 30 days (Sep 19th - Oct 18th 2023)







Note



Meta only provides 7, 30 and 90 days windows for the targeting data in their Ad Library. Metaâ€™s data also lags by a few days. Report will be updated as soon as new data is available.


For Google platforms, data accessed via the Google Transparency Report provides spending on how much money was spent by parties. In order to fit the Meta ranges, we also show the last seven and 30 days.






Disclaimer



The data shown in this dashboard is based on the platformâ€™s respective ad libraries which are known to be sometimes incomplete (Edelson et al.Â 2020; Silva et al.Â 2020). For this reason the data shown here might not reflect the full picture nor all political ads that were targeted at voters.




About the Creator of the Dashboard











Fabio Votta is a Postdoc at the University of Amsterdam who studies (online) political microtargeting and its usage around the world.











Want to see how political parties target you? Sign up at Who Targets Me and download the gratis browser plugin to see how parties on Facebook use your data:
https://whotargets.me/







Want to retrieve targeting data from the Facebook Ad Library yourself? This dashboard is powered by the R package: metatargetr. Check it out here:
https://github.com/favstats/metatargetr




Election Targeting Dashboards
A list of election dashboards:

title: 2023 Montenegrin legislative election
text:
Methodology
In collaboration with Who Targets Me, we monitored rread_lines(â€œn_advertisers.txtâ€)political advertisers in Montenegro during the 2023 Montenegrin legislative election to better understand how campaigns use different targeting methods made available by Meta. To do this, we used data from the Meta Ad Library, using the new â€˜Audienceâ€™ data which gives some detail on how pages target their ads.
To better understand the election, we kept only advertisers who:

Advertised in the last 7 days (May 31st - Jun 6th 2023)
Advertised in the last 30 days (May 8th - Jun 6th 2023)


Note: Meta only provides 7, 30 and 90 days windows for the targeting data in their Ad Library. Metaâ€™s data also lags by a few days. Report will be updated as soon as new data is available.



Election Targeting Dashboards
A list of election dashboards:

ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± 2021 Dutch parliamentary election (15th-17th March 2021)
ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª 2021 German federal election (26 September 2021)
ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª 2022 Swedish general election (11th September 2022)
ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ 2022 United States midterm elections (8th November 2022)
ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ 2022 United States midterm elections - Georgia Runoff (6th December 2022)
ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¹ 2023 Lazio & Lombardy regional election (12-13th February 2023)
ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡ª 2023 Estonian parliamentary election (5th March 2023)
ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± 2023 Dutch provincial elections (15th March 2023)
ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡ª 2023 Montenegrin presidential elections (19th March 2023) - 1st round
ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡º 2023 New South Wales state election (25th March 2023)
ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡® 2023 Finnish parliamentary election (2 April 2023)
ğŸ‡¹ğŸ‡· 2023 Turkish general election (14 May 2023) - Round 1
ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª 2023 Bremen State election (14 May 2023)
ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡· 2023 Greek Legislative election (21 May 2023)
ğŸ‡¹ğŸ‡· 2023 Turkish Presidential election (14 May 2023) - Round 2
ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡ª Montenegrin parliamentary elections, 2023 (11 June 2023)



About Us






Fabio Votta


Ph.D. candidate in Political Communication at the University of Amsterdam who studies (online) political microtargeting and its usage around the world.
Link





Who Targets Me


Grassroots activist group advocating for transparency in the digital age by monitoring political adverts on social media and their impact on democracy.
Link

title: Impressions
text:
Total Impressions

MinimumMaximum

title: 2023 Montenegrin Election Dashboard
text:
Over Time Impressions

MinimumMaximum

title: Impressions
text:
An impression is counted as the number of times an instance of an ad is on screen for the first time.
~Meta Business Help Center
The Facebook Ad library only provides very broad â€œlowerâ€ and â€œupper boundsâ€ of impressions. The graphs below sum up the lower and upper bounds individually across all parties.

title: Impressions
text:
Impressions Over Time

MinimumMaximum

title: Impressions
text:
Impressions by Gender

The boxplots show the distribution of average audience shares per gender by advertiser.

For every ad, the Facebook ad library provides a â€œpercentageâ€ which relates to the share of men and women have that have seen the ad. So, the audience of an ad could show, for example, that 60% of the users that have seen the ad were women.

All at OncePer Party

title: Impressions
text:
Impressions by Age

The boxplots show the distribution of average audience shares per age group by advertiser.

For every ad, the Facebook ad library provides a â€œpercentageâ€ which relates to the share of the specific demographic that has seen the ad. So, the audience of an ad could show, for example, that 60% of the users that have seen the ad were between 18-24
You can try to remove/add individual age groups to better understand the graph

All at OncePer Party

title: Impressions
text:
Potential Reach






Facebook says about this metric:

This is an estimate of the size of the audience thatâ€™s eligible to see this ad. Itâ€™s based on targeting criteria, ad placements and how many people were shown ads on Facebook apps and services in the past 30 days. ~Meta Business Help Center

Based on that, we can assume that a higher potential reach means that a party was trying to target a broader range of citizen whereas a lower potential reach means the party was engaging in more microtargeting. The boxplots show the distribution of average minimum potential reach by advertiser.

title: Targeting
text: This section shows spending per targeting criteria used by political parties to reach citizens in the run-up to the 2023 Polish parliamentary election for the latest available data. It only includes targeting on Meta platforms (Facebook and Instagram), which offers the most detailed targeting options to political advertisers.

title: Targeting
text:
Running Code
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

1 + 1

[1] 2


You can add options to executable code like this


[1] 4


The echo: false option disables the printing of code (only output is displayed).

title: Targeting
text:
Spending per Targeting Criteria
How much did campaigns spend on different targeting methods? The graphs below show spending overall across all parties and by party.

Note: targeting criteria can overlap so the percentages do not sum up to 100%.


Sep 19th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 30 days)Oct 12th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 7 days)



OverallBy Party





























































OverallBy Party

title: Targeting
text:
Top Targeted (Detailed) Audiences
Here, we show the top targeted audiences for each party for the â€œdetailedâ€ targeting that Meta offers (ranked by amount of Euro spend). Most (but not all) of these audiences are â€œinterestâ€ audiences, i.e.Â the parties targeted people interested in â€œBooksâ€ or â€œPoliticsâ€.

Sep 19th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 30 days)Oct 12th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 7 days)

title: Targeting
text:
Top Contested Audiences
Here, we show the top most contested audiences, i.e.Â where all parties have spent considerable amounts of money competing to reach voters with the same interests.

Sep 19th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 30 days)Oct 12th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 7 days)

title: Targeting
text:
Geographical Targeting
The graphs below show various kinds of location targeting that parties engaged in on Meta platforms. The bigger the area the more money was spend by the party on targeting this location.

Sep 19th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 30 days)



RegionsCities

title: Targeting
text:
Geographical Exclusion
On Meta, political parties can also exclude certain geographical units. The graphs below show which locations were excluded from seeing political advertisements and how much money the parties spend on these ads. The bigger the area the more money was spend on ads excluding this location.

Sep 19th - Oct 18th 2023 (Last 30 days)



RegionsCities

title: Targeting
text:
Age Targeting

Note: targeting criteria can overlap so the percentages do not sum up to 100%.

title: ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡· 2nd 2023 Greek Election Dashboard
text:
Methodology
In collaboration with Who Targets Me, we monitored 584 political advertisers in Greece during the 2nd 2023 Greek legislative election to better understand how campaigns use different targeting methods made available by Meta. To do this, we used data from the Meta Ad Library, using the new â€˜Audienceâ€™ data which gives some detail on how pages target their ads.
To better understand the election, we kept only advertisers who:

Advertised in the last 7 days (Jun 11th - Jun 17th 2023)
Advertised in the last 30 days (May 19th - Jun 17th 2023)







Note



Meta only provides 7, 30 and 90 days windows for the targeting data in their Ad Library. Metaâ€™s data also lags by a few days. Report will be updated as soon as new data is available.








Disclaimer



The data shown in this dashboard is based on the platformâ€™s respective ad libraries which are known to be sometimes incomplete (Edelson et al.Â 2020; Silva et al.Â 2020). For this reason the data shown here might not reflect the full picture nor all political ads that were targeted at voters.




About the Creators of the Dashboard

Fabio VottaAlexandros Gotinakos













Fabio Votta is a Ph.D. candidate in Political Communication at the University of Amsterdam who studies (online) political microtargeting and its usage around the world.



















Alexandros Gotinakos is a predoctoral researcher for the ActEU project at Aristotle University of Thessaloniki. Interested in comparative political behavior, political psychology, and survey methodology.

.














Want to see how political parties target you? Sign up at Who Targets Me and download the gratis browser plugin to see how parties on Facebook use your data:
https://whotargets.me/







Want to retrieve targeting data from the Facebook Ad Library yourself? This dashboard is powered by the R package: metatargetr. Check it out here:
https://github.com/favstats/metatargetr




Election Targeting Dashboards

Top Excluded (Detailed) Audiences
Here, we show the top excluded audiences for each party for the â€œdetailedâ€ targeting that Meta offers (ranked by amount of Euro spend). Most (but not all) of these audiences are â€œinterestâ€ audiences, i.e.Â the parties excluded people interested in â€œBooksâ€ or â€œPoliticsâ€.
